column5: WASHINGTON  July 10 The U.S. State Department has approved the possible sale to Britain of Joint Light Tactical Vehicles and accessories with an estimated worth of $1.035 billion  the Pentagon said on Monday.

column5: TORONTO  July 10 Canada's main stock index rose on Monday  reversing early losses as key sectors including materials and energy rebounded.

column4: Snap shares fall below $17 IPO price for first time
column5: Snap Inc  shares slipped below their initial public offering price of $17 for the first time on Monday  signaling waning investor confidence in the social media company's growth potential as it faces fierce competition.

column4: Statoil drills dry wells off Canada's Newfoundland

column4: Third Point Ultra fund up 0.9 pct in June amid Nestle campaign
column5: LONDON  July 10 Hedge fund Third Point's Ultra fund gained 0.9 percent in June  taking its year-to-date performance to 17.2 percent  a source familiar with the matter said on Monday  giving activist investor Dan Loeb a boost as he pushes for a shake-up at Nestle.

column4: Time Warner's CME to stay in other markets after Croatia  Slovenia exit
column5: PRAGUE Broadcaster Central European Media Enterprises (CME)   has no plans to exit other markets after striking a deal to sell television stations in Slovenia and Croatia  its co-chief executive told Reuters.

column4: INTERVIEW-Time Warner's CME to stay in other markets after Croatia  Slovenia exit

column4: Broadcaster CME selling Croatian  Slovenian stations to cut debt
column5: PRAGUE Broadcaster Central European Media Enterprises (CME) will sell its Croatian and Slovenian operations to United Group's Slovenia Broadband for 230 million euros  ($262.18 million) to pay down debt  sending its shares higher.

column4: With new Camry  Toyota eyes bigger share of ailing U.S. sedan market
column5: TOKYO Toyota Motor Corp  on Monday said it was committed to the ailing U.S. sedan market and that it expected a new model of its Camry  the top-selling passenger car in the United States for decades  to help boost the company's sales in the segment.

column4: Wal-Mart pays $1.65 million to resolve improper drug-billing claims
column5: Wal-Mart Stores Inc has agreed to pay $1.65 million to resolve claims that it violated federal law by submitting claims for reimbursement to California's Medicaid healthcare program that were not supported by diagnosis and documentation requirements.

column4: Wells Fargo says closer to reaching $142 million phony accounts settlement
column5: A California judge has granted a preliminary approval for Wells Fargo & Co's agreement to pay $142 million  and perhaps more  to customers whose credit scores were harmed by its employees creating fake accounts in their names  the bank said on Sunday.

column4: UPDATE 2-Wells Fargo says closer to reaching $142 mln phony accounts settlement

column4: Wells Fargo CEO 'pleased' with preliminary approval of $142 mln class-action settlement
column5: July 9 Wells Fargo & Co president and chief executive Tim Sloan said the company is pleased a California judge has given preliminary approval to a $142 million settlement between Wells Fargo and a group of plaintiffs over its creation of false accounts.

column4: Great Plains  Westar revise $14 billion merger to ease regulator concerns
column5: Utilities Great Plains Energy Inc  and Westar Energy Inc  announced Monday new terms for their proposed $14 billion merger  hoping the revised structure would satisfy regulatory concerns which nixed the previous tie-up plan.
